key_risks: Regulatory and censorship challenges due to strict Chinese internet regulations
Data privacy and security concerns, including multiple data breaches
Antitrust and monopolistic practices, with ongoing lawsuits and regulatory scrutiny
Revenue concentration in advertising, making it vulnerable to economic downturns and shifts in advertiser spending
controversies: Temporary ban on LGBTQ+ content, leading to public outrage and partial policy reversal
Data breach exposing personal information of over 500 million users
Legal disputes over misuse of user data by a former partner
Allegations of anticompetitive behavior and limiting access to data for third-party platforms
social_issues: Ethical concerns over government censorship and freedom of expression
Public backlash over handling of sensitive topics, such as LGBTQ+ content
governance_issues: Close ties with Alibaba, exposing Weibo to antitrust investigations targeting Alibaba's ecosystem
Vulnerabilities in data management practices and compliance with data protection laws

sources.title: Read and delete: How Weibo's censors tackle dissent and free speech
sources.snippet: What was it like working in Weibo's censorship department? There were about 10 managerial-level personnel in the headquarters in Beijing and, at its peak in 2012-2013, about 150 rank-and-file employees in Tianjin. The people in Beijing made broad censorship decisions while the Tianjin staff mainly did streamline work: read a post, delete.

sources.snippet: Maimai was founded in 2013, and formed a partnership with Weibo a short time later. But Weibo ended the tie-up after less than a year over dissatisfaction about the way Maimai was using Weibo's user data.
